Take Cyclohexane and Toluene mixture in a round bottom flask. Put some porcelain pieces in it to avoid bumping while boiling.
Place the RB flask in a heating mantle.
Fix a fractionating column and an adapter on top of the RB flask.
Fit a thermometer in a thermometer cork and place it on the adapter.
Attach a condenser to the adapter and a then a receiver to the condenser.
Fix a round bottom flask in a stand.
Attach two tubes to the two outlets of the condenser as shown and then open the tap.
The condenser gets filled with water.
If you carefully observe, the water passes through the tube, fills the condenser and then come out through one of the outlet. This process is to condense the condenser.
Set the temperature to 82ºC on the heating mantle.

Cyclohexane evaporates, vapours rise through the column, while it passes through the condenser, condensation takes place and therefore Cyclohexane vapour gets collected in liquid form in the RB flask.
Cyclohexane has the lower boiling point (80ºC) and is more volatile. Toluene does not boil at the same temperature as Cyclohexane, so the Cyclohexane will boil out of the mixture first.

Take Ethanol and Water mixture in a round bottom flask. Put some porcelain pieces in it to avoid bumping while boiling.
Place the RB flask in a heating mantle.
Fix a fractionating column and an adapter on top of the RB flask.
Fit a thermometer in a thermometer cork and place it on the adapter.
Attach a condenser to the adapter and a then a receiver to the condenser.
Fix a round bottom flask in a stand.
Attach two tubes to the two outlets of the condenser as shown and turn on the tap.
The condenser gets filled with water.
If you carefully observe, the water passes through the tube, fills the condenser and then comes out through one of the outlet. This process is to condense the condenser.
Set the temperature to 78.4ºC on the heating mantle.
Ethanol evaporates, the vapours rise through the column, while it passes through the condenser, condensation takes place and therefore Ethanol vapours gets collected in liquid form in the RB flask.

Ethanol has the lower boiling point (78ºC) than the water. Because ethanol is more volatile, the vapours contain more ethanol. This process has to be repeated many times before the collected liquid consist of only pure ethanol.
